speaker: Programmer
text: How do I register keyboard events with allegro?

speaker: Apiza
text: Something like ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_DOWN?

speaker: Apiza
text: If you have an event ```ev```, you can check the value of ```ev.keyboard.keycode```.

speaker: Apiza
text: You do not need to specifically register the keyboard, though it should be installed with\n```bool al_install_keyboard(void)```

speaker: Programmer
text: What header do i need to include for the allegro key events

speaker: Apiza
text: Events and keyboard input are included in the allegro.h header.

speaker: Programmer
text: What are the allegro event key right and allegro event key left variables called

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_KEY_LEFT and ALLEGRO_KEY_RIGHT are key codes, which are returned in the event.keyboard.keycode field of the ALLEGRO_KEY_DOWN and ALLEGRO_KEY_UP events.

speaker: Programmer
text: how to pop elements off the allegro event queue

speaker: Apiza
text:
The function

```void al_wait_for_event(ALLEGRO_EVENT_QUEUE *queue, ALLEGRO_EVENT *ret_event)	```

speaker: Apiza
text: Description: Wait until the event queue specified is non-empty. If ret_event is not NULL, the first event in the queue will be copied into ret_event and removed from the queue. If ret_event is NULL the first event is left at the head of the queue.

speaker: Programmer
text: Is there a timeout to wait for an event?

speaker: Apiza
text: Do either of these functions look useful?\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
```bool al_wait_for_event_timed(ALLEGRO_EVENT_QUEUE *queue,
 ALLEGRO_EVENT *ret_event, float secs)```

```bool al_wait_for_event_until(ALLEGRO_EVENT_QUEUE *queue,
 ALLEGRO_EVENT *ret_event, ALLEGRO_TIMEOUT *timeout)```

speaker: Programmer
text: What is ALLEGRO_TIMEOUT

speaker: Apiza
text:
ALLEGRO_TIMEOUT

```typedef struct ALLEGRO_TIMEOUT ALLEGRO_TIMEOUT;```

speaker: Apiza
text: Represent a timeout value. The size of the structure is known so it can be statically allocated. The contents are private.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Initialized with\n\n```void al_init_timeout(ALLEGRO_TIMEOUT *timeout, double seconds)```

text: what is the function signature of al_get_timer_event_source

speaker: Apiza
text: ```void al_set_timer_speed(ALLEGRO_TIMER *timer, double new_speed_secs)```

speaker: Apiza
text: Correction:\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ```ALLEGRO_EVENT_SOURCE *al_get_timer_event_source(ALLEGRO_TIMER *timer)```

speaker: Programmer
text: please provide more information about al_wait_for_event_timed

speaker: Apiza
text: al_wait_for_event_timed:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Wait until the event queue specified is non-empty. If ret_event is not NULL, the first event in the queue will be copied into ret_event and removed from the queue. If ret_event is NULL the first event is left at the head of the queue.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: secs determines approximately how many seconds to wait. If the call times out, false is returned. Otherwise, if an event ocurred, true is returned.\n\nFor compatibility with all platforms, secs must be 2,147,483.647 seconds or less.

speaker: Programmer
text: what are all the possible allegro event types?

speaker: Programmer
text: What are the allegro keyboard input event types

speaker: Apiza
text: There are about 27 event types, related to KEY, MOUSE, JOYSTICK, TIME, DISPLAY, and TOUCH.

speaker: Apiza
text: The event types related to Key Events are ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_DOWN and ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_UP.

speaker: Apiza
text: The event types related to Key Events are ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_DOWN and ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_UP.

speaker: Programmer
text: how to play a sound with allegro'

speaker: Programmer
text: How to play a sound with Allegro?

speaker: Apiza
text: The simplest method is al_play_sample\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
```bool al_play_sample(ALLEGRO_SAMPLE *spl, float gain, float pan, float speed,
 ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE loop, ALLEGRO_SAMPLE_ID *ret_id)```

speaker: Apiza
text: Plays a sample on one of the sample instances created by al_reserve_samples.

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns true on success, false on failure.

speaker: Apiza
text: Playback may fail because all the reserved sample instances are currently used.

speaker: Programmer
text: What is ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE

speaker: Programmer
text: What is ALLEGRO_SAMPLE_ID

speaker: Apiza
text: That refers to an enum.

speaker: Apiza
text: Options are ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_ONCE, ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_LOOP, or ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_BIDIR

speaker: Apiza
text: Regarding ALLEGRO_SAMPLE_ID variable ret_id - if non-NULL the variable which this points to will be assigned an id representing the sample being played.

speaker: Apiza
text: If al_play_sample returns false, then the contents of ret_id are invalid and must not be used as argument to other functions.

speaker: Apiza
text: I was able to find an example function call:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ```al_play_sample(sample, 1.0, 0.0,1.0,ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_LOOP,NULL);```

speaker: Programmer
text: What is an ALLEGRO_SAMPLE

speaker: Apiza
text: An ALLEGRO_SAMPLE object stores the data necessary for playing pre-defined digital audio. It holds a user-specified PCM data buffer and information about its format (data length, depth, frequency, channel configuration). You can have the same ALLEGRO_SAMPLE playing multiple times simultaneously.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Samples are often initialized with the function al_load_sample:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ```ALLEGRO_SAMPLE *al_load_sample(const char *filename)```

Programmer
text: how to display text with allegro

speaker: Apiza
text: There are several functions to display text,

speaker: Apiza
text: the simplest is al_draw_text\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
```void al_draw_text(const ALLEGRO_FONT *font,
 ALLEGRO_COLOR color, float x, float y, int flags,
 char const *text) ```

speaker: Apiza
text: Writes the NUL-terminated string text onto the target bitmap at position x, y, using the specified font.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
The flags parameter can be 0 or one of the following flags:

ALLEGRO_ALIGN_LEFT - Draw the text left-aligned (same as 0).
ALLEGRO_ALIGN_CENTRE - Draw the text centered around the given position.
ALLEGRO_ALIGN_RIGHT - Draw the text right-aligned to the given position.
It can also be combined with this flag:

ALLEGRO_ALIGN_INTEGER - Always draw text aligned to an integer pixel position. This was formerly the default behaviour.

speaker: Apiza
text: Since: 5.0.8, 5.1.4\nThis function does not support newline characters (\\n), but you can use al_draw_multiline_text for multi line text output.

speaker: Apiza
text: Sure thing!\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ```ALLEGRO_FONT *al_load_font(char const *filename, int size, int flags)```\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Loads a font from disk. This will use al_load_bitmap_font_flags if you pass the name of a known bitmap format, or else al_load_ttf_font.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: The flags parameter is passed through to either of those functions. Bitmap and TTF fonts are also affected by the current bitmap flags at the time the font is loaded.

speaker: Apiza
text: ```ALLEGRO_COLOR al_color_cmyk(float c, float m, float y, float k)```\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Return an ALLEGRO_COLOR structure from CMYK values (cyan, magenta, yellow, black).
